thread.title: Diet shift shaped evolution of human ancestors (photos)
thread.title_full: Diet shift shaped evolution of human ancestors (photos) | cleveland.com

author: James Ewinger, The Plain Dealer
title: Diet shift shaped evolution of human ancestors (photos)
text:
CLEVELAND, Ohio -- New evidence suggests that human ancestors may have shifted to a predominantly grass-based diet around 3.8 million years ago -- 400,000 years earlier that previously thought.
The dietary change -- consuming grasses as well as creatures eating the grass -- is one of an array of developments that occurred around the same time in the Pliocene epoch, 2.6 to 5.3 million years ago, according to Naomi Levin of Johns Hopkins University, lead author of a paper on the subject published this month in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
Around this time human ancestors were evolving into creatures that lived on the ground and could move swiftly for longer distances on two legs. As a result, they became more mobile and adaptable to different habitats and changes in their environment.
Together these changes gave early humans a better chance at evolutionary success.
The study focused on 152 fossil teeth samples collected by Yohannes Haile-Selassie, curator of physical anthropology at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History, from the Woranso-Mille study area in the Afar region of Ethiopia.
The teeth were from a mix of animals including monkeys, antelopes, pigs, giraffes, elephants and human ancestors.
The carbon isotope distribution in the teeth was the target because it indicates what the creatures ate during teeth formation.
"This research reveals surprising insights into the interactions between morphology and behavior among Pliocene primates," said Haile-Selassie, who was a co-author of the paper and leader of the research project behind it.
"The results not only show an earlier start to grass-based food consumption among hominins and baboons but also indicate that behavioral change does not always precede form," he said.
"In the earliest baboons, dietary shift toward grass occurred before its teeth were specialized for grazing. On the other hand, hominins have acquired dental morphology that would allow them to eat grass-based food resources as early as 4.2 million years ago," Haile-Selassie said. "However, they did not start fully exploiting these food resources until after 3.8 million years ago."
An advantage to the expanded diet is "you can then range wider," Levin said of the human precursors that would have included several species including Australopithecus afarensis , extinct some 3 million years ago and represented most famously in the fossil informally known as Lucy. "You can be in more places, more resilient to habitat change."
Animals with more specialized diets are more vulnerable to extinction, because changes in habitat can eliminate the staple upon which they rely, Haile-Selassie said.
Prior to the dietary expansion, Haile-Selassie said, human ancestors maintained a tree- and shrub-based diet.
After the expansion, they could also consume warm-growing-season grasses and sedges, as well as crassulacean acid metabolism plants that include cacti and succulents.
The researchers said grass-based foods are not limited to grasses and their roots, but also the tissue of creatures that ate grass, such as insects and birds.
Beverly Saylor, associate professor of stratigraphy and sedimentology at Case Western Reserve University, was another co-author of the paper.
